metadata.title: Lipophilic decavanadate supported by three-dimensional porous carbon nitride catalyst for aerobic oxidative desulfurization

Lipophilic decavanadate supported by three-dimensional porous carbon nitride catalyst for aerobic oxidative desulfurization Jinyang Gu a Maogen Liu b Suhang Xun a Minqiang He b Linlan Wu b Linhua Zhu c Xiangyang Wu a * Wenshuai Zhu b * Huaming Li b a School of Environment and Safety Engineering, Institute of Environmental Health and Ecological Security, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang, 212013, PR China School of Environment and Safety Engineering Institute of Environmental Health and Ecological Security Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 PR China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Energy Research, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang, 212013, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Institute for Energy Research Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 PR China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hainan Normal University, Haikou, 571158, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hainan Normal University Haikou 571158 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Dibenzothiophene (DBT) was oxidized to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2) with the help of O2 and V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst. A supported catalyst of the lipophilic decavanadate/three-dimensional (3D) porous g-C3N4 composite was synthesized by a facile solvothermal method. The lipophilic decavanadate [(C8H17)3NCH3]3H3V10O28 was prepared by combining quaternary ammonium salt with decavanadate through acidification. A series of characterizations indicated that the carrier g-C3N4 obtained through supramolecular self-assembly of melamine, cyanuric acid and urea has a 3D pore structure, and it was conducive to the distributed load of the active center. Then, the composition and morphology of the supported catalysts were analyzed detailedly. Activity experiments demonstrated that the catalyst can achieve the goal of activating molecule oxygen to oxidize refractory aromatic sulfur compounds in diesel under mild conditions. The catalyst can still maintain stable catalytic activity after 5 cycles. Based on the results of GC–MS and ESR characterization, the probable mechanism was proposed. The combination of the lipophilic decavanadate and the carrier carbon nitride solves the problem of interface mass transfer effect between different phases and handicaps in separation and regeneration. Herein, the catalyst exhibits high desulfurization activity and good cycle stability. Keywords Supported catalyst Decavanadate 3D g-C3N4 Oxidative desulfurization Oxygen Introduction With the increasingly strict restrictions on the sulfur content of diesel, green and efficient oxidative desulfurization technology has become an important means to control oil sulfides [1–3]. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) is mainly divided into two steps: the first step is to oxidize the organic sulfide in the diesel to the corresponding sulfone by the action of the catalyst. The second step is that the sulfone compound formed by oxidation is separated through distillation, solvent extraction or adsorption to achieve the purpose of desulfurization [4,5]. Compared with the traditional hydrodesulfurization (HDS) in the industry [6], the advantages of oxidative desulfurization technology are: mild operating conditions (such as no hydrogen source, normal temperature and normal pressure), high selectivity, efficient removal of difficult-to-remove thiophene sulfides (such as DBT, 4-MDBT, etc.), low equipment investment and low operating cost, proving that ODS is a promising desulfurization technology [7–9]. The key to oxidative desulfurization technology is the selection of a suitable oxidant and a highly efficient catalyst [10,11]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) is a kind of polynuclear metal-oxygen cluster having a spatial network structure composed of a transition metal ion and an oxygen atom coordination bridge [12–15]. As a new type of catalytic material, polyoxometalate compounds are widely available in the field of catalysis research because of their easy availability in preparation, simple preparation methods, mild reaction conditions, environmental benignity and easy modulating molecular properties [16–22]. Among them, Keggin-type polyvanadate catalysts are widely used as catalysts for oxidation reactions due to good redox properties of vanadium atoms [23–25]. At present, there have been many reports on the application of POMs to oxidative desulfurization [26–28]. Since the POMs are generally acidic [16,19,29], the oxidation reaction needs to be carried out in a polar solvent or in the presence of an extractant [30,31]. However, it is generally closer to non-polar solvents for real oils, thus limiting the use of POMs in desulfurization studies [32]. In terms of the choice of oxidants, the oxidants used in the current oxidative desulfurization studies are mainly peroxides [33,34] and molecular oxygen [35–37]. The suitable bond length of VO in the vanadium-based catalyst facilitates the production of peroxy intermediates peroxides to accomplish the oxidation of sulfur-containing substrates [38], and thus many of the reported oxidative desulfurization systems typically employ peroxide as the oxidant [39–42]. Molecular oxygen, especially oxygen in the air, as a green cheap and easily available oxidant, own a better application potential than peroxide. It has always been the focus of oxidative desulfurization research. Nonetheless, the triple ground state structure of oxygen means the difficulty of being activated [43]. So far, there have been few reports of utilizing oxygen in the air as an oxidant in the vanadium-based catalyst desulfurization system. In this paper, lipophilic vanadate was first synthesized and a carbon nitride (g-C3N4) material with a three-dimensional (3D) porous structure was chosen as a carrier to prepare a supported catalyst. The interfacial mass transfer effect between the catalyst phase and the oil phase was reduced and the problem of separation as well as the recycle of the catalyst was solved [44–47]. 3D porous g-C3N4 is synthesized through a self-assembly method under suitable conditions using melamine, cyanuric acid, and uric acid as raw materials. The synthesized g-C3N4 has a rich 3D pore structure, which is beneficial to the adsorption of the active center thereby achieving a high dispersion. Meantime, it is reported that g-C3N4 with mesoporous structure can adsorb sulfur compounds efficiently to form local high concentration on its surface and promote the oxidation efficiency [48]. When the oxygen in the air is used as the oxidant, the prepared supported vanadium-based heterogeneous catalyst exhibits excellent desulfurization activity for different aromatic sulfur compounds. Meanwhile, the mechanism of the catalysis reaction were investigated and discussed on the basis of GC–MS and ESR characterization results. Experimental section Preparation of lipophilic decavanadate All chemicals used in this work are analytical reagent grade and commercial available. 4.5 g NaVO3 was dissolved in 25 mL deionized water in a 60 °C oil bath. Then 6.2 mL phosphoric acid (1.5 mol/L) was added, and the pH was adjusted to 5.5 with nitric acid (1.5 mol/L). A black-red solution was obtained under vigorous stirring. After that, 0.54 g KCl was added slowly into the solution subsequently. Cooling down to ambient temperature naturally, the orange-yellow crystal K3H3V10O28 was precipitated and dried after filtration. 1.1 g K3H3V10O28 was dissolved in a hydrochloric acid solution of pH = 5.5 in a 60 °C oil bath. Then 1.21 g, 3 mmol [(C8H17)3NCH3]Cl was dissolved into 6 mL ethanol, which was subsequently added dropwise into the solution of K3H3V10O28. Under stirring continually for 2 h, an orange-yellow solid was formed. The obtained [(C8H17)3NCH3]3H3V10O28 solid was separated by filtration and vacuum seasoning at 60 °C for 24 h, which was labeled as V-IL. Preparation of 3D porous graphitic carbon nitride The carrier graphitic carbon nitride having a three-dimensional porous structure was synthesized by a self-assembly method based on the reported literature [49]. Using melamine, cyanuric acid and urea as raw materials, the total amount is 8 g and their molar ratios are adjusted to 1:1:3. The three raw materials were dissolved in 80 mL ethanol, stirred at ambient temperature for 3 h and sonicated for 3 h. The suspension was then stirred in an oil bath at 60 °C until no obvious liquid was observed, and it was dried in an oven at 60 °C to obtain a white powder. The white powder was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. The obtained pale yellow powder was labeled as 3D g-C3N4. Preparation of V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst The V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst was synthesized using a solvothermal method. A certain amount of 3D g-C3N4 powder and the corresponding amount of [(C8H17)3NCH3]3H3V10O28 (equal to 10%, 20% and 30% vanadium element) were added into ethanol solution under stirring for 1 h. Then the solution was transferred to a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave lined with Teflon, sealed and kept at 100 °C for 24 h. After lowering to ambient temperature, the resulted precipitate was separated by filtering and dried for 3 h. The corresponding catalysts were marked as x-V-IL/3D g-C3N4, where x means the theoretical load of vanadium element. Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on XRD-6100 (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a Cu-target tube, by a scanning rate of 7° min-1 over the 2θ range from 5° to 80°. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were conducted on a Nicolet Nexus 470 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets as the media. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using a JSM-6010PLUS/LA electron microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was operated by Hitachi H-700 microscope. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) was obtained by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The GC–MS analysis was collected on Agilent 7890/5975C-GC/MSD (HP-5 MS column) to detect the oxidation product of DBT. Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra were carried out at ambient temperature on a JES FA200 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) was taken using a NETZSCH STA449 F3 Jupiter thermal analyzer under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from ambient temperature to 800 °C. Catalytic reaction Using dodecane as the solvent and hexadecane as the internal standard substance, DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT were used to simulate the sulfur-containing substrate in the real fuel and were respectively fixed to a model oil of 200 ppm sulfur content. The typical oxidative desulfurization reaction was carried out in a 100 mL three-necked flask. 20 mL model oil and 0.01 g catalyst were added into the flask and stirred under 1000 rpm at the specified temperature. The reaction used oxygen in the air as an oxidant and the flow rate of the air is set to 100 mL· min-1. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h to ensure adequate contact of the catalyst with the sulfur-containing substrate in model oil before the oxidation desulfurization reaction. During the oxidation reaction, the upper oil was withdrawn periodically and analyzed by gas chromatography. Results and discussion Characterization of as-prepared samples FT-IR analysis was carried out to verify the successful preparation and loading of the catalyst [50]. As shown in Fig. 1 , the peak of the catalyst at 960 cm-1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the terminal VO bond of the vanadium-based ionic liquid [51]. The absorption peak around 600 to 850 cm-1 can be assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibration of VOV bond, while those at 400 to 600 cm-1 can be attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of VOV bond [52]. The telescopic vibration of the CH bond of V-IL is from 2840 to 2960 cm-1. The absorption bands at 1240–1640 cm-1 are associated with the typical NCN heterorings of g-C3N4, while the sharp peak at 811 cm-1 denoting the out-of-plane bending vibration of tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4 [49]. These results demonstrate the successful synthesis of vanadium-based ionic liquids and supported carbon nitrides. Meanwhile, characteristic peaks of V-IL at 960, 2855 and 2925 cm-1 can be seen in the FT-IR spectrum of the catalyst, demonstrating the successful loading of V-IL on 3D g-C3N4. And no obvious characteristic peaks of V-IL are detected in the spectrum of the lower loading catalysts (10%V-IL/3D g-C3N4 and 20%V-IL/3D g-C3N4), presumably due to the good dispersion of V-IL, which is also confirmed by XRD patterns and TEM images subsequently. Fig. 2 is the X-ray diffraction patterns of as-synthesized V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalysts. A peak appearing in 27.1° can be indexed as (002) phase of graphitic materials [53], originating from the periodic stacking of layers in the three-dimensional structure of carbon nitride. Due to the poor crystallinity of V-IL, only two low-intensity characteristic peaks at 8–10° and 20–24° were observed. With the increase of the loading, the diffraction peaks of catalysts at 27.1° are broader, implying a lower degree of crystallinity [54]. This may be due to V-IL entering the pore structure of the carbon nitride. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks (at 8–10° and 20–24°) of the ionic liquid gradually appear, which can be observed intuitively from the pattern of 30%V-IL/3D g-C3N4. Those indicate the good dispersion of V-IL on carbon nitride, which is consistent with the previous results. SEM and TEM analyses were performed to give an intuitive exhibition of the textural details of the catalysts [55–57]. As shown in Fig. 3 A and C, carrier carbon nitride is a three-dimensional material that is stacked from many pore structures. After the solvothermal treatment, V-IL enters the pore structure of the carbon nitride, causing some pore structure to be blocked and some pasty object appearing on the surface of the carbon nitride. It can also be observed from the TEM image (Fig. 3D) that a clearly uniform fuzzy substance appears on the pore structure of 3D carbon nitride, indicating the V-IL dispersed load. Combined with previous results, it proved that the carbon nitride material having a three-dimensional porous structure contributes to the good dispersion of the active center. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) gas sorptometer measurements were conducted to investigate the effect of loading on the specific surface area and porous structure of synthesized catalyst V-IL/3D g-C3N4. Fig. 4 (A) shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of 3D g-C3N4 and V-IL/3D g-C3N4. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms exhibit a typical type IV curve with an H3 hysteresis loop [58], demonstrating the mesoporous characteristics [59,60]. The isotherm does not exhibit adsorption saturation at high relative pressures, implying that the pore structure is mainly formed by stacking slit structures [61]. It is in good accordance with SEM and TEM images. Then, the pore size distribution is presented in Fig. 4(B). The pore size distribution curves show that most of the pores fall into the size range of 2−20 nm. In addition, the BET surface areas of synthesized V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The specific surface area of V-IL is only 1.54 m2/g, but after the loading, the specific surface area of V-IL/3D g-C3N4 is increased to 36.91, 46.99 and 37.43 m2/g respectively. As the load increases, the pore volume of V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst declined slightly from 0.1695 cm3/g to 0.1108 cm3/g due to V-IL entering the pore structure and the same phenomenon also appears in the results of the pore size (15.99 nm–10.10 nm). In a word, the result of the N2 adsorption-desorption experiment proves that the utilization of carbon nitride as a carrier increases the specific surface areas of V-IL to expose more active sites. Due to the probable loss of V-IL during the solvothermal treatment, TG analysis was carried out in an air atmosphere to determine the real content of V-IL in catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 , the introduction of V-IL promotes the combustion of 3D g-C3N4. The mass-loss of V-IL/3D g-C3N4 was advanced to 400 °C, while pure 3D g-C3N4 beginning to decompose at 550 °C, implying the synergic effect between V-IL and carrier 3D g-C3N4. The same circumstance has been reported previously for supported catalysts [62]. When the temperature rises to 800 °C, the remainder of the catalyst is V2O5, while carrier carbon nitride has completely decomposed. Herein, the real content of V-IL in V-IL/3D g-C3N4 composites can be estimated from the remaining V2O5 mass after heating above 800 °C. As can be seen from Table 2 , the actual loading of V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst is 6.36% (10%V-IL/3D g-C3N4), 9.15% (20%V-IL/3D g-C3N4) and 24.61% (30%V-IL/3D g-C3N4) respectively. This shows that there will be some V-IL loss during the solvothermal process, resulting in the actual load being lower than the theoretical load. Evaluation of oxidative desulfurization activities ODS performance of the as-synthesized V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalysts were examined via using O2 in the air as oxidant and DBT-containing dodecane as model oil at 120 °C. Before the reaction, the mixture of model oil (20 mL) and a minute quantity of catalysts (0.01 g) were stirred for 0.5 h to ensure adequate contact of the catalyst with the sulfur-containing substrate. First, the desulfurization activity of different catalysts was investigated. It can be observed from Table 3 that the active center decavanadate [(C8H17)3NCH3]3H3V10O28 exhibits a certain catalytic activity while the desulfurization efficiency of decavanadate can only reach 43.7% after 6 h for the acidity of heteropoly acid. Then, after the introduction of 3D g-C3N4 without obvious desulfurization activity, the activity of the catalyst was significantly improved. The desulfurization efficiencies of different V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalysts are 90.5% (10% V-IL/3D g-C3N4), 97.2% (20% V-IL/3D g-C3N4) and 89.4% (30% V-IL/3D g-C3N4) after 6 h, respectively. When the loading of V-IL is 20%, the catalyst exhibits the outstanding activity (residual sulfur content < 10 ppm), possibly because of the appropriate loading beneficial to expose sufficient active sites and the good lipophilicity. Herein, 20% V-IL/3D g-C3N4 was selected as the catalyst in the subsequent activity test. In order to explore the removal effect of the catalyst on other refractory sulfur compounds, 4-MDBT and 4,6-DMDBT were chosen. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that the oxidative desulfurization system of different refractory sulfur compounds can reach the target of deep desulfurization target after 6 h in the following order: DBT > 4-MDBT > 4,6-DMDBT. There are two main factors affecting the oxidative desulfurization activity of different substrates. One is the electron cloud density of S atom [63], and the other is the steric hindrance of methyl groups [64]. In this experiment, the S atomic electron cloud density of the three substrates is not much different, while the electron density of sulfur atom in DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT is 5.758, 5.759 and 5.760, respectively [64]. Therefore, the steric hindrance of methyl is the decisive effect on the level of oxidative activity. Although the highest steric hindrance of 4,6-DMDBT leads to the worst desulfurization activity, the residual sulfur content of 4,6-DMDBT can still be reduced to 8.4 ppm in 6 h. The composition of real oils is complex, not only containing various sulfides, but also other substances such as olefins and aromatic hydrocarbons [65]. In order to simulate the desulfurization process of the catalyst in real oil, here we added 5 wt% cyclohexene and p-xylene separately to simulate olefins and aromatic interferences present in real oil during the oxidation reaction. The results of the interfering experiments (Fig. 7 ) show that the presence of interfering substances reduces the desulfurization rate of the desulfurization system to some extent, but it can still achieve an effective removal of DBT after 8 h, which proves that the catalyst has superior selectivity. In order to investigate the stability of the supported catalyst, the cycle performance of 20%V-IL/3D g-C3N4 was investigated. After each run, the oil phase was dumped carefully, and the catalyst phase was dried under 100 °C for the next cycle experiment. As shown in Fig. 8 , the desulfurization efficiency of 20%V-IL/3D g-C3N4 decreased slightly after 5 cycles. But the desulfurization efficiency can still reach 95.2% (residual sulfur content is 9.6 ppm) after 6 h. Then, when the reaction time of each cycle experiment was set at 2 h, a similar result was obtained. The desulfurization efficiency decreased slightly from 48.3% to 45.7%. There are two possible reasons for these results. On the one hand, the oxidation product of DBT produced in the reaction process could be adsorbed on the surface of the supported catalyst, which hindered part of the reactions. On the other hand, there might be a slight loss of the catalyst during each circulation. Even so, it can be concluded that the supported catalyst exhibited good cycling performance and stability. ODS mechanism in V-IL/3D g-C3N4/O2 system In order to illustrate the reaction pathway of the catalytic oxidation system, we investigated the oil phase and catalyst phase after the reaction by GC–MS analysis. After the end of the oxidation reaction, we collected the remaining precipitate by centrifugation and extracted it with carbon tetrachloride. As shown in Fig. 9 , the result shows that the oxidation product after the end of the reaction is only DBT sulfone (DBTO2, m/z = 216) [66], indicating that the DBT in the model oil was oxidized to form a polar substance DBTO2 under the V-IL/3D g-C3N4/O2 oxidation system. To further illustrate the oxidation mechanism during the reaction, ESR characterization was utilized to detect free radicals that may be generated during the oxidation reaction. As the ESR result (Fig. 10 A) showed, no significant peak was detected when no catalyst was added. When the catalyst was added, an obvious four-fold peak signal could be detected, ascribed to the O2 − radicals [67]. The same result was also obtained by a radical scavenging experiment. The radical scavenging experiments selected BQ and TBA as scavengers for O2 − and O H, respectively. The results (Fig. 10B) show that the presence of BQ greatly inhibits the catalytic oxidative desulfurization effect of the system, and indirectly proves that the intermediate activation product of the oxidation reaction process is O2 − radical. Based on previous characterization results, a possible mechanism was proposed and showed in Fig. 11 . The carrier carbon nitride provides a rich pore structure and achieves an effective load of the active center V-IL. The lipophilic V-IL improves the compatibility of the catalyst with the oil phase which is beneficial for the mass transfer in the heterogeneous system. The active center V-IL motivates O2 in the air to generate O2 − radicals and then O2 − radicals interact with the catalyst to form the peroxy intermediate [68]. Subsequently, an oxidation reaction occurs with the sulfur-containing substrate which was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst in the model oil. The sulfur-containing substrate is oxidized to form a polar sulfone species, thereby achieving the purpose of removing sulfides from the oil. The synergistic effect of the lipophilic V-IL and the three-dimensional porous carrier carbon nitride provides efficient mass transfer and high catalytic activity for the catalyst simultaneously, which establishes a reliable ODS system. Conclusion The lipophilic vanadate supported by three-dimensional porous carbon nitride V-IL/3D g-C3N4 catalyst was successfully synthesized through a solvothermal method. According to the characterization results, the active center successfully entered the pore structure of carbon nitride to achieve a more uniform load. The lipophilic vanadate is combined with the carrier carbon nitride to enhance the mass transfer of reaction and the cycle stability of the catalyst. The results of the activity experiments demonstrated that minute quantity (0.01 g) of the catalyst can achieve the goal of activating the oxygen in the air to oxidize different refractory organic sulfur compound in model oil into polar sulfone species. In summary, high catalytic activity, low catalyst dosage, high selectivity, and stable recyclability made V-IL/3D g-C3N4 heterogeneous catalyst to be a new promising catalyst for application in deep ODS process. coredata.dc:description: A supported catalyst of the lipophilic decavanadate/three-dimensional (3D) porous g-C3N4 composite was synthesized by a facile solvothermal method. The lipophilic decavanadate [(C8H17)3NCH3]3H3V10O28 was prepared by combining quaternary ammonium salt with decavanadate through acidification. A series of characterizations indicated that the carrier g-C3N4 obtained through supramolecular self-assembly of melamine, cyanuric acid and urea has a 3D pore structure, and it was conducive to the distributed load of the active center. Then, the composition and morphology of the supported catalysts were analyzed detailedly. Activity experiments demonstrated that the catalyst can achieve the goal of activating molecule oxygen to oxidize refractory aromatic sulfur compounds in diesel under mild conditions. The catalyst can still maintain stable catalytic activity after 5 cycles. Based on the results of GC–MS and ESR characterization, the probable mechanism was proposed. The combination of the lipophilic decavanadate and the carrier carbon nitride solves the problem of interface mass transfer effect between different phases and handicaps in separation and regeneration. Herein, the catalyst exhibits high desulfurization activity and good cycle stability.
coredata.dc:title: Lipophilic decavanadate supported by three-dimensional porous carbon nitride catalyst for aerobic oxidative desulfurization
